University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China A series of NbCoO x catalysts with different Nb/Co molar ratios were synthesized via a slurry method to investigate the catalytic activity of oxidizing toluene. Among them, Nb0.67Co0.33O x exhibited the highest toluene combustion efficiency. It was found that the incorporation of amorphous niobium provided the surface acid sites and abundant oxygen vacancies for the adsorption and activation of the reactants which was demonstrated by NH3-TPD, XRD, UV–vis DRS, XPS and Toluene-TPD. Furthermore, the strong interaction between niobium and cobalt can also affect its physical and chemical properties related to SEM, H2-TPR and XPS. Multiply TP-experiments were conducted to investigate the migration and transformation of oxygen species and find out that the reaction followed the MVK mechanism. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords NbCoO x Toluene Catalytic oxidation Oxygen species 1 Introduction VOCs (volatile organic compounds) are the main precursors of PM2.5 and ozone in the atmosphere which can cause damage to the ecological environment and human health. The key to the improvement of air quality is to strengthen the coordinated emission reduction of nitrogen oxides and VOCs. Catalytic oxidation was one of the most promising methods for VOCs treatment due to its advantages of high efficiency and low cost [1–3]. The core of catalytic oxidation is to develop highly efficient, economical, and versatile catalysts [4–6]. Co3O4, a typical transition metal oxide, has achieved much attention for its highly lattice oxygen fluidity, low strength of Co-O and outstanding performance on various types of VOCs combustion [7–11]. Recently, Co-based catalysts have been extensively studied and exhibited highly catalytic activity in oxidation reaction. Li et al. designed a bimetallic CoCeO x catalyst which performed well in the oxidation of typical VOCs due to the increase of oxygen vacancies [12]. Xue et al. developed a CoFe-LDO catalysts with highly hydrothermal stability [13]. Interactions between different bimetallic oxides can significantly affect the structure and chemical properties. NbO x has been widely used for its highly oxygen storage capacity and strong acidity. Zhang et al. reported that Nb-doped CuO x /CeO x catalysts exhibited high CO conversion under low energy input due to its effect on oxygen vacancies [14]. Li et al. prepared NbCo-MOF catalyst maintaining good performance on removing several organic pollutants [15]. Ali et al. synthesized Cu x Nb1.1-x bimetal oxides catalysts on NH3-SCR, and found that the acid amount and the redox reaction between Nb and Cu leaded to the excellent low temperature activity [16]. Knowledge gained from studies that no reports exist synthesizing Nb-Co bimetallic catalysts for the catalytic combustion of toluene. Hence, a series of NbCoO x catalysts with different Nb/Co molar ratios were synthesized via a slurry method to investigate the catalytic activity of oxidizing toluene. Furthermore, the effect of Nb incorporation on the structure, redox ability and oxygen species were extensively studied using various characterization techniques. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Nb x CoO1-x (x = 0, 0.33, 0.67, 0.75, 1) composite oxides were prepared by a slurry method. Typically, an amount of ammonium niobate oxalate hydrate (C4H4NNbO9·x H2O, Aldrich, 99.99%) and cobalt nitrate (Co (NO3)2) was dissolved in deionized water (30 ml/0.01 mol). After stirring at ambient temperature for 10 min, the solution was heated to 90ºC under stirring until water evaporated completely. Then the consequently solid materials were dried at 110ºC in an oven overnight and calcined at 400ºC (5ºC /min) for 4 h in a muffle furnace under air atmosphere. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiment was recorded on a Bruker AXS-D8 Advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) with a scanning rate of 5° min−1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis was carried out on a Hitachi S-4800 electron microscope at 200 Kv. The morphology of the samples was characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20). N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms at about − 196ºC were obtained using a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 instrument. All the samples were degassed at 220 ºC for 4 h. The specific surface area of the samples was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The pore size distributions were determined from desorption branches by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The data of Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy UV–visible (UV-Vis DRS) were recorded in the range of 200–800 nm using model 1800 made by Shimadzo Japan. X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) was measured using on a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi with a monochromatic X-ray source of Al Kα under ultra-high vacuum (3–2 ×10−6 Pa), spectra were analyzed using XPS PEAK41. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and O2 temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) were performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument equipped with the TCD detector. For H2-TPR, the catalysts were pretreated in Ar flow at 300ºC for 1 h and then cooled to 80ºC. After that, the catalysts were heated to 800ºC (10ºC/min) under a steady flow of 10% H2 in Ar gas mixture to reduce the sample. For O2/NH3-TPD, the catalysts were pretreated in He/Ar flow at 300ºC for 1 h and cooled to 50ºC afterward. Then the gas mixture (30 ml/min) of 5%O2/He or 10% NH3/Ar was introduced to absorb for 1 h. Pure He/Ar was purged to remove the excess O2/NH3. Then the desorption was conducted by heating the temperature to 800ºC (10ºC/min). The designed temperature-programmed (TP) experiments were recorded by the Hidden QIC-20 mass spectrometer (MS) detector. For toluene temperature programmed desorption (Toluene-TPD), the catalysts were pretreated at 150ºC under a He flow for 1 h to remove the surface weakly adsorbed water and carbon dioxide. When the temperature dropped to ambient temperature, toluene was purged until the baseline in the MS was stable. After saturation, He was purged to remove the physically adsorbed toluene till the baseline was stable. Then the reactor was heated to 500ºC (5ºC /min) under the He flow, and toluene (m/z = 92), water (m/z = 18), CO2 (m/z = 44), and other possible intermediate products were monitored. In Toluene-TPSR, the difference from Toluene-TPD was that the heating process took place under 20% O2 and He flow. For (Toluene +O2)-TPD, toluene and O2 were co-adsorbed during the adsorption conditions. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests The catalytic activity tests for toluene oxidation were conducted in a continuous quartz tubular fix-bed reactor (i.d.=6 mm, length =45 cm) under atmospheric pressure. Catalysts (nCo=0.00125 mol) were diluted by quartz sand and the total filling amount maintained at 0.6 g. The flow rate controlled by Bronkhorst mass flowmeters was 100 ml/min containing 1000 ppm toluene (cooled in the ice bath and bubbled by He flow) and a mixture of O2 and He. The outlet mixture was analyzed by online gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890 A) equipped with a KB-17 capillary column (30 m * 0.53 mm*1.00 µm) and a flame ionization detector. Toluene conversion ( X C 7 H 8 ) was calculated based on the following equation: (1) X C 7 H 8 = C 7 H 8 in − [ C 7 H 8 ] out [ C 7 H 8 ] in × 100 % Where [ C 7 H 8 ] in and [ C 7 H 8 ] out represented the toluene concentration of inlet and outlet, respectively. 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of the five catalysts was investigated for the toluene oxidation as shown in Fig. 1a, and the reaction temperatures of T50, T90 (corresponding to toluene conversion of 50% and 90%) were summarized in Table 1 to compare the catalytic activity. Compare to pure CoO x (T50 =265 ℃, T90 =275 ℃), NbO x based catalysts showed higher catalytic performance. The temperature of 90% toluene conversion for Nb0.33Co0.67O x , Nb0.67Co0.33O x and Nb0.75Co0.25O x were 266ºC, 262ºC and 271ºC, respectively. It can be seen that proper Nb addition could enhance toluene conversion and Nb0.67Co0.33O x (T50 =256ºC, T90 =262ºC) achieved the highest activity. Besides, the pure NbO x showed no catalytic activity for toluene oxidation. Meanwhile, the apparent activation energy (Ea) and the turnover frequency (TOF) were also calculated to evaluate the catalytic performance. The TOF of these catalysts at 243ºC were calculated according to Eq. (2). (2) TOF Co = [ C 7 H 8 ] in × X C 7 H 8 × V gas n Co ( s − 1 ) Where X C 7 H 8 is the conversion of toluene, Vgas (mol s−1) is the total molar flow rate, and nCo (mol) is the molar quantity of Co for the catalyst. It was found that Ea (Fig. 1b and Table 1) followed the sequence: Nb0.67Co0.33O x (131.4 kJ/mol) < Nb0.33Co0.67O x (133.6 kJ/mol) < CoO x (140.4 kJ/mol) < Nb0.75Co0.25O x (199.1 kJ/mol). In addition, Nb0.67Co0.33O x had the largest TOF value among all the catalysts. These results were in consistent with the catalytic performance. In addition, the reaction of toluene oxidation performed on other catalysts in the previous studies also summarized in Table 2. The Nb modified CoO x catalysts in our study showed more excellent catalytic oxidation performance of toluene. The stability test was essential for the synthetic catalysts. As seen from Fig. 1c, a long-period test was conducted at 260ºC over Nb0.67Co0.33O x catalyst. The catalyst continued to react for 50 h with no significant decrease in toluene conversion. Interestingly, the toluene conversion increased significantly after reacting 30 h. Then the catalyst after reaction was characterized by XRD (Fig. 1d), and it was found that no significant change of the intensity of Co3O4 diffraction peak occurred. This indicated that the grains had no obviously growth after long-term stability test. The exploration of the increased activity will be published in the next part of our work. 3.2 Structure and textural analyses The X-ray diffraction was used to study the structure of these catalysts as displayed in Fig. 2. It was noted that the peak at 19.1, 31.3, 36.9, 38.6, 44.8, 55.7, 59.3 and 65.2° can be assigned to the (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511) and (440) lattice planes of the spinel Co3O4 phase (JCPDS 42–1467), respectively. Interestingly, no characteristic diffraction peaks of Nb2O5 phase (JCPDS 28–0317) were observed over the NbCoO x catalysts, indicating its highly amorphous structure [23]. Moreover, the addition of Nb weakened the diffraction peak intensity of Co3O4, indicating the formation of smaller-sized Co3O4 crystallites. In detail, the crystallite size was 38, 20, 20 and 22 nm for CoO x , Nb0.33Co0.67O x , Nb0.67Co0.33O x and Nb0.75Co0.25O x , respectively. It can also be found from SEM ( Fig. 3) that the particle size became smaller with the addition of Nb. The EDS-mapping analysis of Nb0.67Co0.33O x further confirmed that the Nb, Co and O elements were homogeneously distributed. The TEM images of the NbCoO x catalysts are displayed in Fig. 4. The morphology of the catalysts showed obviously change after Nb modification. Pure CoO x exhibited an irregular rod-like structure. However, Nb0.33Co0.67O x , Nb0.67Co0.33O x and Nb0.75Co0.25O x catalysts appeared to show an irregular spherical structure. The particle size gradually decreased with the increase in the Nb content, which was in consistent with the results of SEM. The HRTEM images showed good crystallization of CoO x , the interlayer spacing of 0.245 and 0.283 nm in CoO x were attributed to the (311) and (220) plane of Co3O4, respectively. Furthermore, no lattice fringes of NbO x were observed in the Nb modified catalysts, which indicated that Nb existed in an amorphous state. This result was in consistent with the XRD results. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the pore size distribution curves of the NbCoO x catalysts are plotted in Fig. 5. All the catalysts showed type-Ⅳ isotherms with a H3 hysteresis loop in the relative pressure (p/p0) range of 0.7–1.0, which represented the presence of mesopores. The mesopore structure was further confirmed by the pore-size distribution from 2 to 30 nm in Fig. 5b. The surface areas and pore characterization of NbCoO x are summarized in Table 1. Nb0.67Co0.33O x exhibited the highest specific surface area and pore volume value of 31 m2/g and 0.13 cm3/g, respectively. 3.3 UV–vis DRS analysis The UV–vis DRS spectra obtained from the Schuster-Kubelka-Munk (SKM) equation for NbCoO x catalysts are presented in Fig. 6. The band at 210–250 nm can attributed to charge transition from the 2p electron on the oxygen atom to the 3d empty orbital on the cobalt and niobium atom [24]. The band at 315 nm can be assigned to the higher coordination state (octahedral) typical of bulk niobium oxide [25]. The NbO x showed no characteristic bands in the visible light. Then the absorption edges of NbCoO x were shifted to the visible light region. This is most probably due to the hybridization of the Co 4 s and O 2p orbitals [26]. According to Sass et al. [27–29], the band around 370 nm was attributed to Co2+ corresponding to the 4T1g (F)→4T1g (P) transition. The CoO x presented bands at 656 nm can be ascribed to Co3+ species of the A1g→T1g transition, indicating Co3O4 species existed in the NbCoO x catalysts, which were in good agreement with XRD analysis. However, it is worth noticing that the curve of NbCoO x was red-shifted (a shift to higher wavelengths) relative to CoO x from 656 nm to 732 nm due to the incorporation of Nb, which suggested the stronger interaction between cobalt and niobium [26]. Meanwhile, the intensity of adsorption bands at around 700 nm assigned to Co3+ decreased as Nb content increased [30]. The band gap (Eg) of the NbCo x was calculated from Tauc plot in Eq. (3), here hv (eV) is the photon energy and the value of n is 2 for indirect transitions and 1/2 for direct transitions (Fig. 1S and Table 3). The band gap increased with the increasing of Nb content, as the substitution of Co2+ and Co3+ with Nb5+ might induce their energy states to extend into the Co3O4 conduction band, resulting in the extending of the band gap [31]. (3) (αhv)1/n=A (hv-Eg) 3.4 Surface Elemental analysis XPS was used to investigate the surface component and chemical state of those catalysts. Fig. 7 shows the Co 2p, O 1 s and Nb 3d of the as-fabricated samples, and the corresponding fitting results are summarized in Table 3. As displayed in Fig. 7, the curves of Co2p spectra were composed four distinct peaks at 780.3 ± 0.4 eV (2p3/2), 795.6 ± 0.4 eV (2p1/2) and two shake-up satellite peaks (790.1 ± 0.2 eV and 805.2 ± 0.2 eV). The Co 2p3/2 bands could be deconvoluted into two component peaks at 779.6 ± 0.1 eV and 781.4 ± 0.2 eV, assigned to Co3+and Co2+, respectively [32,33]. Moreover, the Binding energy of Co 2p3/2 for the catalysts was increased distinctly from 779.9 eV to 780.7 eV with the addition of the Nb. This implied the strong interaction between Nb and Co, which was in consistent with the results of UV–vis DRS. For the Co2p1/2 peak, Co3+ and Co2+ were located at 795.0 ± 0.2 eV and 797.7 ± 0.1 eV, respectively. As listed in Table 3, the CoO x catalysts displayed the highest amount of Co3+ which would lead to the reduction of surface oxygen vacancies according to the electroneutrality principle [34]. The transformation of Co3+ to Co2+ would produce oxygen vacancy to balance charge, exhibited by the following equation [35]: Co3+ + (O-O)- → Co2+ + Ov + O2 (Ov: oxygen vacancy) Positively charged oxygen vacancy was readily to combine with the negatively charged oxygen ions to supple the missing lattice oxygen atom [36,37]. Therefore, the higher oxygen vacancy concentration was conductive to the adsorption, dissociation and activation of O2. The O 1 s XPS of NbCoO x catalysts could be deconvoluted into three peaks at 529.7 ± 0.1 eV, 530.4 ± 0.2 eV and 531.5 ± 0.2 eV, which attributed to surface lattice oxygen (Olatt, O2-), surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads, e.g. O2 -, or O-) and chemical adsorbed water (Ow), respectively [32,38]. The Oads/O (Oads +Olatt+Ow) ratios increased with the increasing of Nb content as illustrated in Table 3. Notably, a higher Oads/O molar ratio signified more oxygen vacancies [39]. The exist of oxygen vacancy could promote the conversion of gaseous oxygen to surface adsorbed oxygen. Fig. 7 also showed the XPS spectrum of Nb 3d for NbCoO x . The peaks at 207.3 ± 0.1 eV and 210.2 ± 0.1 eV were assigned to Nb 3d5/2 and Nb 3d3/2 represent Nb5+, respectively [24,40]. The presence of high-priced Nb5+ can effectively improve the oxygen vacancy concentration of the material because the mix-valance change of Co would be forced to change the valance from high to low states to balance the charge (Co3+→Co2+) [41]. This was also consistent with the result that the proportion of Co3+ decreased in Co 2p and UV–vis DRS. According to XRD result, Nb existed in an amorphous state, while the amorphous metal oxides could provide rich oxygen vacancy for its rapid surface self-reconstruction, weak lattice constraint and charge localization [42–45]. Then, it would appear that amorphous Nb could dramatically enrich the oxygen vacancy to enhance the adsorption of gaseous oxygen and possess greater mobility for oxygen cycle to accelerate the catalytic combustion of toluene. 3.5 Reducibility analysis H2-TPR was conducted to test the reducibility of the samples displayed in Fig. 8. For pure CoO x , the H2 consumption peak centered at lower temperature (292ºC) was corresponded to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, and the reduction peak at higher temperature(331ºC) could be attributed to CoO →metallic Co [7,8]. For the NbCoO x catalysts, the peak at lower temperature (α peak) located at 256, 252 and 280ºC for Nb0.33Co0.67O x , Nb0.67Co0.33O x and Nb0.75Co0.25O x , respectively, represented the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO. It is noteworthy that the addition of Nb made it easier to reduce the Co3O4 species to CoO. This could facilitate the formation of the hexagonal close-paked cobalt (Co hcp) phase which has more stacking faults and defect sites [46]. While the peak at higher temperature (β peak) at 314, 320 and 335ºC could be attributed to the reduction of Co2+ to metallic Co for Nb0.33Co0.67O x , Nb0.67Co0.33O x and Nb0.75Co0.25O x , respectively. The TPR profile of the Nb0.67Co0.33O x catalyst presented a reduction peak at 544ºC, and Nb0.75Co0.25O x showed reduction peaks around 439ºC and 538ºC. However, Nb oxides are hardly reduced below 800ºC according to previous studies [47,48]. Thus, these peaks supposed to be the reduction of Co2+, probably linked to Nb [49]. The amount of hydrogen consumption of the four catalysts was displayed in Table 3. The amount of H2 consumption was 5.3, 5.4 and 3.1 mmol/g for Nb0.33Co0.67O x , Nb0.67Co0.33O x and Nb0.75Co0.25O x , respectively. It was worth noticing that the hydrogen consumption of Nb modified CoO x catalysts decreased significantly compared to pure CoO x (10.9 mmol/g). This may attribute to the formation of Co-O-Nb oxide species which could not be easily reduced, so the consumption of H2 dropped remarkably [50]. Furthermore, the strong interaction between cobalt and niobium also confirmed by XPS and UV–vis DRS results. 3.6 Acidity analysis Nb is a typical solid acid material, so the NH3-TPD was carried out to investigate the surface acid properties of the catalyst ( Fig. 9). No obvious desorption peak was observed for pure CoO x . While he NH3 desorption peak occurred between 100 and 350ºC was attributed to the weak/moderate acidic sites as Nb modified. The acid amounts of NbCoO x catalysts were calculated based on the desorption peak area as shown in Table 3. The mount of NH3 desorption was 0.095, 0.113 and 0.039 mmol/g for Nb0.33Co0.67O x , Nb0.67Co0.33O x and Nb0.75Co0.25O x , respectively. According to the previous study that the hydrocarbon could be adsorbed on surface acid sites by proton transfer [51]. Therefore, the acid sites played a part in controlling the kinetics of adsorption-desorption of reactants and/or intermediate species [52,53]. They could promote the adsorption and activation of toluene, correspondingly enhance toluene oxidation [54,55]. Nb0.67Co0.33O x showed the highest NH3 desorption capacity among the catalysts and performed the best in toluene combustion. 3.7 The surface reaction study To further investigate the toluene adsorption, surface reaction and the role of oxygen species in the catalytic oxidation of toluene over NbCoO x , Toluene-TPD, O2-TPD and Toluene-TPSR tests were carried out. Simultaneously, signals of toluene (m/z = 92) and the formed CO2 (m/z = 44) was recorded. Other possible intermediate products like benzoic acid, benzyl alcohol and benzaldehyde were also monitored, but no obviously signal was obtained. As seen in Fig. 10a, the desorption amount of toluene increased greatly after the addition of Nb (nCo=0.00062 mol). This indicated that Nb could effectively promote the adsorption of toluene, which may be related to the increased mesoporous structure of the homodisperse Nb modified CoO x catalysts. Meanwhile, it was worth noticing that the desorption temperature of toluene also increased slightly, which may also affect the diffusion of toluene on the catalyst surface. Two toluene desorption peaks were detected at around 70 and 300ºC, respectively. From Fig. 10b, the desorption of CO2 began at 289, 283, 279 and 313ºC for CoO x , Nb0.33Co0.67O x , Nb0.67Co0.33O x and Nb0.75Co0.25O x , respectively, which was agreed with the toluene oxidation activity. Simultaneously, the formed CO2 in the absence of gaseous oxygen indicated that other oxygen species in the catalysts could react with toluene. Moreover, the formation temperature of CO2 and the peak shape were basically the same, indicating that the same oxygen species were consumed. So O2-TPD (Fig. 10c) was carried out to evaluate the surface oxygen species of the catalysts. The peak observed below 300ºC and above 700ºC were assigned to the desorption of surface physical absorbed oxygen and bulk lattice oxygen, respectively. While the peak between 300 and 700ºC can be assigned to the desorption of chemical adsorbed oxygen and surface lattice oxygen [56,57]. The peak intensity of chemical adsorbed oxygen and surface lattice oxygen increased as the incorporation of Nb. On the contrary, the intensity of bulk lattice oxygen decreased as the molar radio reached to 3. This indicated that the modification of Nb could effectively increase active oxygen species. Overall, it was reasonable to conclude that the chemical adsorbed oxygen and lattice oxygen on NbCoO x catalysts could oxidize toluene to CO2 with the absence of gaseous oxygen. When gaseous oxygen was introduced (Fig. 10d), the desorption of CO2 peak moved to the lower temperature. This demonstrated that the existence of gaseous oxygen significantly decreased the reaction temperature and accelerated the oxidation reaction. Moreover, the Nb0.67Co0.33O x displayed the largest CO2 desorption peak area, which explained the best catalytic activity of Nb0.67Co0.33O x catalyst had. To better understand the role of gaseous oxygen and Nb in toluene oxidation, Toluene-TPD, (Toluene+O2)-TPD and Toluene-TPSR were carried out on CoO x and Nb0.67Co0.33O x catalysts. As shown in Fig. 11, the formation temperature of CO2 on Nb0.67Co0.33O x were lower than that of CoO x . Moreover, the amount of generated CO2 on Nb0.67Co0.33O x catalyst was noticeably higher than that of CoO x catalyst among all the TP-experiments, indicating the existence of Nb effectively promoted the adsorption and oxidation of toluene. When the toluene and O2 were co-adsorbed on the CoO x , the decreased area of CO2 desorption peak was ascribed to the competitive adsorption between toluene and O2 on the catalysts. During Toluene-TPSR, the temperature of CO2 formation (201ºC) on Nb0.67Co0.33O x were much lower than toluene-TPD (317ºC) and (toluene+ O2)-TPD (334ºC) after the purging of gaseous oxygen. This suggested that the lattice oxygen could be activated to participate in the oxidation of toluene at higher temperature. Sun et al. used Situ-DRIFTs to study the adsorption and transformation of toluene on OMS-2 with/or without gaseous oxygen, confirmed that the presence of gaseous oxygen could affect the formation of adsorbed species on catalysts and lattice oxygen can deeply oxidize C-H species to CO2 [58]. Therefore, the presence of gaseous oxygen may accelerate the oxidation reaction by affecting the formation of intermediate species. Meanwhile, the similar shape of CO2 desorption peak indicated that lattice oxygen played the major role in the reaction. To further investigate the depletion and replenishment of oxygen species on NbCoO x catalysts, designed multiple toluene-TPD experiments were carried out ( Fig. 12). According to O2-TPD, the surface adsorbed oxygen would be completely removed at 450ºC. So, the Nb0.67Co0.33O x catalyst were pre-treated under helium at 150 and 450ºC, respectively. However, for the Nb0.67Co0.33O x catalyst pre-treated at 450ºC, the desorption of CO2 peak could still be observed. This further proved that lattice oxygen participated in the reaction. It was generally accepted that the oxidation reaction involved lattice oxygen followed Mars-van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism [59,60]. The formation temperature of CO2 increased from 261 to 291ºC comparing to the Nb0.67Co0.33O x catalyst pre-treated at 150ºC. This proved that the existence of surface adsorbed oxygen was beneficial to the oxidation of toluene at lower temperature. Two more continuous toluene-TPD were carried out to consume the reactive oxygen species and the signal of CO2 basically disappeared. Then gaseous oxygen at 25ºC was supplied and CO2 began to produce at 172ºC, demonstrated that gaseous oxygen could quickly replenish surface active oxygen species to oxidize toluene at lower temperature. Some researchers also investigated the speed of the migration and transformation process of oxygen species. Qin et al. designed multiples experiments with isotopic 18O2 to investigate the transformation of oxygen species during toluene oxidation, found that the consumption and replenishment of oxygen species were simultaneous and quickly during the whole reaction [61]. Dong et al. also found that the migration between gaseous oxygen and lattice oxygen were easily though designed Situ-TP experiments and Situ Drifts [62]. It was reasonable to conclude that Nb modification could provide abundant oxygen vacancies. Meanwhile, the strong interaction between Nb and Co also weaken the Co-O bond to facilitate the migration of lattice and surface adsorbed oxygen [63]. Moreover, the presence of coupled Co3+/Co2+ allowed the electron exchange and promoted the oxygen mobility. Thus, the toluene oxidation reaction followed the MVK mechanism over NbCoO x catalysts was proposed in Fig. 13. The possible reaction path was that the lattice oxygen oxidized toluene to CO2, then the consumed lattice oxygen can be quickly replenished by the surface adsorbed oxygen which can be transformed by the gaseous oxygen adsorbed on oxygen vacancy, thereby an oxygen cycle was formed to oxidize toluene at low temperature. 4 Conclusions Nb0.67Co0.33O x exhibited the highest toluene combustion efficiency among the series of NbCoO x catalysts during the catalytic oxidation of toluene. It was related to the abundant oxygen vacancies, surface acid sites and the strong interaction between niobium and cobalt. The modification of Nb can significantly improve the adsorption of toluene and enrich the oxygen vacancy for the adsorption and activation of gaseous oxygen, meanwhile the strong interaction between Nb and Co weaken the Co-O bond, and the presence of coupled Co3+/Co2+ allowed the electron exchange, which both promoted the oxygen mobility. The whole reaction followed the MVK mechanism, an oxygen cycle was formed and demonstrated the excellently low temperature oxidation of toluene. coredata.dc:description: A series of NbCoO x catalysts with different Nb/Co molar ratios were synthesized via a slurry method to investigate the catalytic activity of oxidizing toluene. Among them, Nb0.67Co0.33O x exhibited the highest toluene combustion efficiency. It was found that the incorporation of amorphous niobium provided the surface acid sites and abundant oxygen vacancies for the adsorption and activation of the reactants which was demonstrated by NH3-TPD, XRD, UV–vis DRS, XPS and Toluene-TPD. Furthermore, the strong interaction between niobium and cobalt can also affect its physical and chemical properties related to SEM, H2-TPR and XPS. Multiply TP-experiments were conducted to investigate the migration and transformation of oxygen species and find out that the reaction followed the MVK mechanism.
coredata.dc:title: Nb-modified CoO x as efficient catalysts for toluene oxidation
